I do lots of testing of graphics code.  Sometimes the effort is not  
worth the payback, but you have to at least consider what it would  
take.  Simply saying "I can't test it" without exploring how it could  
be tested is a cop-out.

The first barrier is usually ignorance.  I don't know how or what I  
would test.
The second, is environment and tool support.  This isn't an issue  
with Java.

Some things may be hard to test, some may just require some kinds of  
thinking you haven't done before.

For instance, I have a component that paints on top of another.  I'm  
not going to test the exact image produced by a complex combination  
of transparencies, but I can get mileage out of filling the decorator  
a solid color and ensuring the corners of the bounds of the decorator  
show up the right color.

I've implemented a host of custom UI components, whose response to  
user input can be tested with native OS events, stuffing the java  
event queue, or pushing them programmatically.

There are links to several JUnit-based UI testing tools at junit.org  
and http://groups.yahoo.com/groups/java-gui-testing
